articles.headline: Life Story of Wendy Davis Swings From Strength to Flash Point in Texas Campaign
articles.snippet: A race for governor has led to second-guessing over the candidate’s biographical omissions and has sparked a debate about a woman’s balance of work, ambition and parenthood.
articles.abstract: A race for governor has led to second-guessing over the candidate’s biographical omissions and has sparked a debate about a woman’s balance of work, ambition and parenthood.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Wendy Davis is learning the perils of campaigning on her personal biography.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Citing Growth, Fed Again Cuts Monthly Bond Purchases
articles.snippet: In a unanimous decision, the Federal Reserve said it would pull back on its stimulus program by another $10 billion, pointing to an improving economy.
articles.abstract: In a unanimous decision, the Federal Reserve said it would pull back on its stimulus program by another $10 billion, pointing to an improving economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In its final major decision under the leadership of Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it would continue to slowly dismantle its stimulus campaign, citing “growing underlying strength in the broader economy.”

articles.headline: After Big Bet, Google Is to Sell Motorola Unit
articles.snippet: Though not a total financial loss, the announced sale of the smartphone unit for $2.91 billion, less than two years after Google paid $12.5 billion for it, is a sign of fits and starts at the company in the mobile age.
articles.abstract: Though not a total financial loss, the announced sale of the smartphone unit for $2.91 billion, less than two years after Google paid $12.5 billion for it, is a sign of fits and starts at the company in the mobile age.
articles.lead_paragraph: Larry Page, Google’s co-founder and chief executive, likes to talk about “big bets” and “moonshots.” But the thing about moonshots is that they can crash into earth.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and David Gelles

articles.headline: Be Careful at the Book Club, the Author Might Be There
articles.snippet: Book the Writer, a new service, brings authors to book clubs.
articles.abstract: Book the Writer, a new service, brings authors to book clubs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The living room in the plush apartment on Central Park West was filled with all the trappings of a traditional book club.

articles.headline: Big Profit at Facebook as It Tilts to Mobile
articles.snippet: The social networking giant reported that 53 percent of its advertising revenue in the fourth quarter came from mobile devices.
articles.abstract: The social networking giant reported that 53 percent of its advertising revenue in the fourth quarter came from mobile devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ten years after its founding as a simple website for a few thousand Harvard undergraduates to manage their social lives, Facebook is a far different company.

articles.headline: As China’s Economy Slows, the Pain Hits Home
articles.snippet: Emerging markets are heavily exposed to any economic slowdown in China, but the most vulnerable producers may be the mines and farms in China itself.
articles.abstract: Emerging markets are heavily exposed to any economic slowdown in China, but the most vulnerable producers may be the mines and farms in China itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Piles of unsold coal line rural roads in north-central China. Some iron ore mines near Beijing are operating at a fraction of capacity. Chinese farm products are even increasingly scorned by the Chinese consumer.

articles.headline: Personal Trainer, Worn on a Wrist
articles.snippet: The Force, new from Fitbit, opens a window on your exercise habits. But it still requires a good bit of work from you.
articles.abstract: The Force, new from Fitbit, opens a window on your exercise habits. But it still requires a good bit of work from you.
articles.lead_paragraph: My first experience with a fitness tracker was memorable. It fit snugly in my pocket and estimated the number of steps I took and the calories I burned each day. There was just one problem: It seemed to think I was getting roughly the same amount of exercise regardless of whether I was jogging around a track or eating French fries in a diner. After about two weeks, I stopped wearing it, most likely because I lost it.

articles.headline: Wall Street’s New Housing Bonanza
articles.snippet: Banks have begun selling bonds backed by foreclosed homes turned into rentals in the United States, bringing calls for Congress to look into the deals.
articles.abstract: Banks have begun selling bonds backed by foreclosed homes turned into rentals in the United States, bringing calls for Congress to look into the deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s latest trillion-dollar idea involves slicing and dicing debt tied to single-family homes and selling the bonds to investors around the world.

articles.headline: U.S. Says Russia Tested Missile, Despite Treaty
articles.snippet: American officials believe Russia tested a new ground-launched cruise missile, raising concerns about Moscow’s compliance with an arms deal that has been viewed as a bedrock accord in ending the Cold War.
articles.abstract: American officials believe Russia tested a new ground-launched cruise missile, raising concerns about Moscow’s compliance with an arms deal that has been viewed as a bedrock accord in ending the Cold War.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States informed its NATO allies this month that Russia had tested a new ground-launched cruise missile, raising concerns about Moscow’s compliance with a landmark arms control accord.

articles.headline: Economy Is Expanding, but Obama’s Legacy May Be Slipping Away
articles.snippet: As the economy shrugged off the effects of the government shutdown and debt standoff, economists said President Obama faced an uphill battle to burnish his economic legacy before leaving office.
articles.abstract: As the economy shrugged off the effects of the government shutdown and debt standoff, economists said President Obama faced an uphill battle to burnish his economic legacy before leaving office.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years into the Obama presidency, the American economy is finally showing some momentum.

articles.headline: Obama and G.O.P. Facing Opposition to Trade Pacts
articles.snippet: President Obama, supported by many Republicans and business groups, has met opposition from labor and many Democrats on his push for fast-track approval of trade deals with Pacific Rim nations and Europe.
articles.abstract: President Obama, supported by many Republicans and business groups, has met opposition from labor and many Democrats on his push for fast-track approval of trade deals with Pacific Rim nations and Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For companies like General Electric and Honeywell, it would help open untapped global markets, lift exports and create middle-class American jobs. For labor groups like the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Teamsters, it is a threat to American workers, bound to lead to lost jobs and lower wages, as well as rising corporate profits.
